sessions.name: Code Labs
sessions.desc: Polymer code labs provide a guided, tutorial, hands-on coding experience. Learn and build elements and applications with the Polymer Team. **BYOL (Bring Your Own Laptop)**

sessions.name: Opening Keynote
sessions.speaker: Matthew McNulty & Taylor Savage
sessions.desc: A warm welcome to the first ever Polymer Summit. We'll talk briefly about how we're thinking about Polymer's past, present, and future, and get the show on the road.

sessions.name: Using Vanilla Polymer aka Building Apps with Polymer
sessions.speaker: Kevin Schaaf
sessions.desc: Polymer embraces encapsulated Custom Elements as its main organizing unit.  This simple-sounding concept is actually an incredibly powerful tool that can revolutionize how you think about solving complex problems, collaborate within large teams, reduce technology lock-in, and of course, build amazing apps for the web.  Hear how we think about building apps using custom elements directly from one of the Polymer core team engineers, and how to best employ this simple concept for the most leverage in your own projects.

sessions.name: End to End with Polymer
sessions.speaker: Rob Dodson
sessions.desc: Developers are really excited by Polymer and Web Components, but they're not always sure how to connect the dots to get a full blown, production-ready app. Where should you store your data? How do you handle user authentication? What are the patterns that make up a good Polymer app? In this session I'll answer these questions, and guide you through the process of building an awesome offline-first Progressive webapp using Polymer Starter Kit, the Platinum elements, and Firebase.

sessions.name: Using Polymer on the Bleeding Edge: ES6, other future web platform features with Polymer
sessions.speaker: Eric Bidelman
sessions.desc: Polymer's mission is to evolve with modern web. In this 3-part talk, we'll discuss the state of web components and where things are headed. Then, we'll cover tips for building a fast Polymer app today. Finally, learn how bleeding edge standards like ES6, Web Animations, and CSS snap points are playing a role in Polymer's future. If there's not an element, we'll create one!

sessions.name: Testing Polymer Web Components
sessions.speaker: Chris Joel & Dan Freedman
sessions.desc: This session will include a rundown of test environment helpers we have created, the new test-fixture element and the accessibility testing functionality added to WCT. We will also cover examples of different non-trivial testing scenarios related to web components and provide strategies to address them.

sessions.name: Platinum Elements
sessions.speaker: Mat Scales
sessions.desc: Web Components aren't the only hot new thing on the web. Learn about how we're bringing the magic of Polymer to brand new Web Platform features like Offline, Push Messaging, and Background Sync.

sessions.name: There’s an Element for that — but what if there isn't?
sessions.speaker: Surma
sessions.desc: You have your own service. It has a very nice API. Is there an element for that? Probably not! In this session we’ll talk about patterns that occur when writing your own elements while wrapping an API or while writing new visual elements.

sessions.name: Adaptive UI with Material Design and Paper Elements
sessions.speaker: Zach Gibson, Yuin Chien, & Addy Osmani
sessions.desc: A look into Material Design's latest thinking around adaptive user interface design patterns and best practices. Polymer's paper elements make it easy to design cross form factor.

sessions.name: Polymer's Styling System
sessions.speaker: Monica Dinculescu
sessions.desc: Traditionally, CSS stylesheets have a terrible opinion about style encapsulation: the only thing stopping one element’s style from stomping over another’s is a “well chosen class name”. The Shadow DOM fixes this by building a little castle and a moat around each element, so that styles can’t get in and out of the web component castle. But what happens if you _do_ want to style this custom element? How do you cross the moat? Custom properties, that’s how.

sessions.name: Polymer's Animation System
sessions.speaker: Yvonne Yip
sessions.desc: Great transitions and animations are an important part of your web application's visual design. However building them using CSS and Javascript is not always straightforward. In this talk we'll cover how neon-animation system helps you build animations in Polymer and we'll build some page transitions.

sessions.name: Lightning Talk: Upgrading to 1.0 with polyup
sessions.speaker: Peter Burns
sessions.desc: A lot changed from Polymer 0.5 to 1.0! Fortunately you don't have to upgrade all of your code by hand, polyup will do a lot of the work for you. We'll walk through upgrading a full app from 0.5 to 1.0 in under ten minutes.

sessions.name: Lightning Talk: Polymer's Gesture System
sessions.speaker: Dan Freedman
sessions.desc: A look at the breadth and depth of Polymer's built-in gesture library, and how your elements can be interactive, responsive, and cross-platform.

sessions.name: A11y with Polymer
sessions.speaker: Alice Boxhall & Laura Palmaro
sessions.desc: One in six people will experience a disability at some point in their life, so it's crucial for sites and apps to work smoothly for users with a wide range of abilities. A well crafted site is usable whether or not a person can see, use a mouse, or distinguish red from green - to mention just a few of the assumptions we inadvertently make. Come and learn about how and why we hold the Polymer 1.0 widget set to a high bar for accessibility, and how you can use the Polymer libraries to create your own accessible custom elements.

sessions.name: Polymer Power Tools
sessions.speaker: Addy Osmani
sessions.desc: In 2015, framework-less web development using elements + micro-libraries can get you really far on the web platform. It's powerful. We'll cover the tools now available to help you build with Polymer in production including Polymer Starter Kit, Polyup, Vulcanize, Crisper, web-component-tester, our docs and code viewer tools and much more!

sessions.name: Performance Patterns in Polymer
sessions.speaker: Eric Bidelman
sessions.desc: Let's face it, building web apps is hard. There's a lot to remember! Web components allow us to componentize the web's best practices but that doesn't mean footguns are a thing of the past. In this talk, we'll cover tips and tricks for building fast Polymer apps right from the start.

sessions.name: Doing a Perf Audit of your Polymer App
sessions.speaker: Paul Irish
sessions.desc: Performance is measured from the ground truth of the browser internals, and you're operating a few levels up, with the DOM, framework code, and JavaScript sitting between your users finger and the resulting screen paints. In this session Paul Irish will show how the Chrome DevTools can help you understand where time is spent in your app and effective means of profiling your performance. You'll walk away with a solid understanding of how your polymer work can be as fast-loading and responsive-to-the-touch as you like.

sessions.name: PolyPanel
sessions.speaker: The Polymer Team
sessions.desc: A wrap-up discussion panel with members of the Polymer team.
